Contributions received by Federal employee retirement plans \2\

Federal and State unemployment insurance taxes
Withheld personal income tax and social security contributions
Equals: Federal Government current receipts, national income and product accounts
Federal Home Loan banks and Federal Land banks
Loan disbursements less loan repayments and sales \10\

Purchases (increase in payables net of advances) \12\
Subsidies less current surplus of government enterprises

Equals: Federal Government current expenditures, national income and product accounts
Consolidated cash budget surplus or deficit (-) (1-19)
Equals: Federal Government surplus or deficit (-), national income and product accounts (18-44)
1. Consists largely of contributions for social insurance by residents of U.S. territories, Puerto Rico, and the Northern
2. These transactions are included in the NIPA personal sector.
3. Consists of estate and gift taxes.
4. Consists largely of sales of land, receipts from offshore oil leases, and U.S. Treasury receipts from sales of foreign
5. Taxes received from the rest of the world are included in receipts in the cash budget and netted against expenditures
6. Consists largely of sales of goods and services and interest receipts that are recorded as receipts in the cash budget and
netted against expenditures in the NIPA's.
7. Consists of transfer payments, subsidies, and grants-in-aid to residents of U.S. territories, Puerto Rico, and the Northern
8. Net investment is gross investment less consumption of fixed capital for government enterprises and general government.
9. Consists of investment grants to State and local governments and maritime construction subsidies.
10. Also includes the financial transactions of deposit insurance funds.
11. Consists largely of offshore oil leases and purchases of land, certain purchases of foreign currency from the U.S. Treasury
expenditures of foreign currencies, grants to the District of Columbia, and net purchases of silver and minor coin metal.
12. Consists largely of real estate transactions, sales of military equipment to foreign countries, purchases of farm
commodities, and purchases of defense equipment and supplies.
Note.  In this time period, fiscal year estimates reflect a July 1-June 30 fiscal year.
NIPA quarterly and fiscal year estimates in this table are consistent with the not seasonally adjusted estimates published in
